comments.text: This is a really good place to hitch! Get off the bus right after the toll gates and hitch from the bus stop. Bus fare 42 pesos (May 2014). Took me only a couple of minutes to get a ride going to Punta del Este.
there are several buses going to Peaje Pando from Terminal Rio Branco.

Going from Montevideo to the east, this is the best spot to hitch hike.

HOW TO GET HERE:
In Montevideo, you go to the bus stop in the corner of Minas and Paysandú, near to the Plaza de los Bomberos. There you can take the bus 711 (wich costed 40 uruguayos on octobre 2013) until "Peaje de Remanso de Neptunia", you walk a few meters after the toll and rise your thomb!

We first tried to hitchhike to go southwards from a gas station inside the city (Ancap) but almost all drivers were returning to the city or heading north. We got a ride from there to a point outside of the city (about 5km) where many trucks stop. There were dozens of them parked on the left side of the road when going south. We waited less than a minute until the first truck went out of that parking and picked us up!
Beginning of two-lane road, perfect to hitch out of La Barra further east along the Ruta 10 towards Manantiales / Jose Ignacio. After Manantiales, the road is easy hitchable along itself.
Hitchhiking spot (roundabout) just out of La Barra, perfect to hitch to Maldonado / Punta del Este. Lots of traffic, bus stop available with space to stop cars. Be aware of mosquitos.
I was walking to the town and after a minute I got offered a ride even without any gestures to the driver.
you can usually also get a ride to or from the town, then on routa 10, it´s easy.
Just behind Devoto supermercado, there's  a great spot to hitchhike up to Maldonado or further.

I hitchhiked in a police station and a restaurant here with a friend (we're 2 guys). Thought it would be hard because it was almost 8pm (on the summer, so we still had sun shining), but soon a truck driver and a car driver which stopped at the restaurant offered us a ride to south. We guess the truck driver was going straight to Montevideo, but we choose the car driver which took us to Carmelo, next to Colonia del Sacramiento.

Peaje pro Interbalneario:  From Montevideo catch bus number 700 which brings you directly to this place (the last stop!). It is perfect to go to Punta del Este or Cabo Polonio, Punta del Diablo ect. If you wanna go to Punta del Diablo or Cabo Polonio ect. and they can't carry you the whole way I recommend you to make sure they go for Route 9 (San Carlos, Rocha ect..) There is a lot more traffic and chances a quite high somebody will pick you up. In general the weekend works way better, but if yo
Tried taking the ferry first, but it only goes with 4 or more people, so we decided to hitchhike. We hitched while walking to the main road and got a ride straight to Salto.
Easy to get a ride to Ruta 9 and 10.
Don't visit the park. It has a very lonely Jaguar in a too small enclosure. The hitching back to the city is easy though. We were 3 guys and got a ride in the back of a small pickup.
Cars stop at the side of the road and have a market closer
Easy to get a ride from the immigration checkpoint. Plenty drivers heading south to Punta del Diablo/Castillos
Bus stop. Sign "Paysandu".
Hitchhiking spot at the entrance/exit to/of La Paloma. There's space on the side to stop cars.
Nice spot to go to rocha
In May 2013: 5min with 4 people to La Paloma, 3min (2 people) to Rocha. Traffic low.
Crossing of Ruta 10 with Ruta 15. To Rocha, La Paloma (15) and Cabo Polonio (10). There's plenty of space on all sides to stop cars in several directions. Even a busstop with shadow.
Nice spot to go to paloma. Not good to go to Castillo. If you want go to Castillo,  éter to go to paloma, rocha and then castillo.
nearly no traffic! but still worth a try
in the first comment, I meant to say less traffic than on routa 9 :)
Less traffic than on Routa 10, but still easy - people here give want to give you a lift - in the car or at the back of the lorry :)

If it is often long waiting times til we hitch a ride from Chuí towards Pelotas. If that has been the case with you, I'd recommend writing on a paper the name of one of these places  on the way: Mangueiras or Quatro irmãos. These are some sort of farms on the way, there's absolutely nothing around these farms, but trucks come in and out loading stuff produced by in the region. This can be a way of moving some kilometers if you are stuck, since truck drivers might want to pick you up thinking tha
Me and my female friend waited for 2 hours only thumbing. Make a sign. Let it be Santa Victoria, Porto Alegre, Pelotas, or whatever. But make ANY sign.

I hitch hiked here to Santa Victoria do Palmar, on october 2013. A man stopped his car for me and leave me in a good point in Santa Vitoria to hitch hike to Porto Alegre. From Chuy (Uruguay) to the Brazilian front office you have to walk like 3 km. I recomend to go very early in the morning.

If you want to hitch hike to Porto Alegre, Pelotas or Rio Grande, the check point on the brazilian side. Is the best place. After people get checked you can easyly ask for a ride. But you need to walk like 2 km out of town!
we went by walking to Cabo POlonio and got a free ride from a truck for tourists.
Walk from the town to Routa 10, then it´s pretty easy to get a ride.

We were so lucky to find somebody after 5 minutes who brought us to the Route 9 (Castillos) where more cars are passing. But you can also try Route 10 which is probably nicer.... (but less traffic at least in november, maybe it is better during holiday time in december and january..)
We waited about 20min for a ride in this spot called la "Virgencita". A pick-up took us all the way to Tacuarembó!

I don't know exactly where it is to point in the map, but I was here hitchhiking with a friend and everybody was telling us to go to the "virgenzita" (little Madonna) which is on top of a hill guess it's around 8km from downtown. People said it's comun to see people hitchhiking there. When we were walking and hitchhiking in the same time going to this place, someone stopped and took us to the aduana (customhouse) which I guess all the trucks getting to Uruguay have to stop to check their documen
Just before the bridge, direction Montevideo. Low traffic
take bus from terminal rio branco to playa pascual (2 options) and get off at PEAJE NUEVO, perfect place
Because there is a toll station cars don't go too fast and there is enough place to stop. You can come here very easy by bus from Montevideo.
It's also a good spot to hitch hike to Chuy and the border wirh Brasil.

Best spot to hitchhike towards Montevideo is not down at the roundabout, but a few hundred meters up the hill behind the traffic lights. If one wants to be totally safe, walk towards the end of city, there's also some sort of bus stop.
Bus stop with plenty of space in front of it to stop cars, as well as good visibilty. For hitchhiking towards La Barra.
This is better to go towards Treinta y Tres o inland - enough traffic to pick you up
yeah, get a cheap public transport bus from Montevideo, then hitch on the main road / IB, plenty of traffic there.
You can get here from Montevideo with a bus and if you walk a little bit more to the east, there is a busstop where the cars can easily stop and pick you up.
I walked out of the town towards Colonia, pass the big factory on your left, and got a ride in about 30 min. but you could also just sit outside the town and wait.

Instead of paying for the boat to Buenos Aires (which was pretty expensive for us) as we had time, we choose to hitchhike to Buenos Aires. I hitchhiked here with a friend (we're 2 guys) around 6am and soon someone stopped.
walk out from the center and position yourself on ruta 1, on the way to montevideo, about half an hour walk out from the center. I stuck my thumb up and got a ride in 15 min.
Cosy spot for hitchhiking out of Colonia towards Libertad, Montevideo. Traffic low, space to stop cars.
In May, two teams started here and got rides in resp. 1 and 5 minutes; first to Chuy (Brazilian border) and second to La Paloma.
Northern roundabout from San Carlos, at the Ruta 9. There's some space behind the roundabout in direction Rocha to stop cars.
Bus stop along Ruta Interbalnearia towards Ciudad de la Costa, Montevideo. Plenty of space, cars see you early enough, though going slightly uphill.
Bus stop and place to stop cars going out of town.
Bus stop behind roundabout and hard shoulder for stopping traffic towards Montevideo.

Behind roundabout there's space to hitchhike out of town. It's the last spot where traffic drives slowly until Sarandi Grande. There's also a police station, though they should be pretty relaxed. Quite some local traffic, be careful and try to get a ride at least till Sarandi Grande.

No shadow, be aware.
Sufficient space for hitchhiking behind the peaje. Traffic is scarce.
Spot out of Canelones, some space to stop. Small service station nearby.
Use the entrance to the parking place as a hitchhiking spot to hitch the traffic coming from Colonia or Rosario going towards Montevideo.
Bus stop behind the roundabout, traffic slow, plenty of space to stop cars towards Colonia.
Place to stop cars just behind the roundabout, traffic drives slowly.
Some place to stop traffic towards Montevideo
Bus stop easily accesable by a service road. Sign "Montevideo".
good spot just off a roundabout with a long place to stop
Nice place to go to punto del diablo or chuy (Brasil bouderie)
Nice spot to go to Castillo
Waited about 20 min (in a couple male+female). There is no good position further up the road as a highway starts soon.
Waited there 3+ hours and gave up eventually. A better spot might be 1-2 km further up the road.
Bus stop behind the roundabout with space for cars to stop.

20 minutes
Cars drive too fast
a spot just after a speed bump
Bus stop along Ruta 39. Good for hitchhiking to San Carlos, space for cars to stop, though traffic is going uphill and already speeds up. Some slow traffic coming from the road on opposite side too.

I'm not completly sure about the spot,  but I guess this is the place we hitchhiked from. It's a good place especially coming from Valizas or Aguas Dulces to get a lift on the highway 9 for example to Montevideo. Cars can stop very well on the hard shoulder but there is not much traffic.
Space to stop cars towards Florida, though better hitchhike somewhat earlier at the end of town.
Bus stop behind roundabout, exit of service station. Not the best spot, but traffic is slow. Later there's less possibilities to stop cars savely.
On-ramp for traffic from the village, traffic on the highway drives fast. Not a spot to recommend, but possible.
Bus stop with plenty of space for cars to stop. Traffic fast, semi-good spot.
On-ramp with bus stop in direction Libertad, possible to hitchhike traffic on the highway.
Small on-ramp, perfect for hitchhiking out of Montevideo in direction of ruta 1 or 5. Possible to hitchhike traffic on the highway as well.

Place to hitch-hike to Montevideo direction. On the top of a hill close 3 trees.
Not so good place, probably it is better to stay close to gasstation before.

We had our difficulties, but it was probably a really bad time (a tuesday around 14 o'clock..) because all way before before worked out perfectly. We finally took a bus after one hour as we had to catch the ferry in Montevideo. But if you are not in a hurry I am quite your you will find somebody in the end...
not a great place to stop as there isnt a long stop area but south americans will usually stop

waited about 3 hours for a ride to Melo.
Little traffic, mostly local cars.
Not a good spot. My friend and I waited for hours and he had to sleep in a gas station and try again next days. Besides the fact that is a dangerous neighborhood.
Bad place. My friend and I waited for hours and we didn't get a ride to Montevideo.
Bad place but not senseless.. We succeed to find a car.
Bad place, cars go very fast and there is not space to stop.
Bad place. We wait 45 minuts and we move to the other point.
Although it´s on the map as one of the main roads, not many people go here. You´re better off going to Chuy and taking the road towards Treinta Tres.

It's a spot I used when going to Montevideo. It's on the turn to some houses. Although it doesn't have a lot of space for cars to stop it's after the turn which a lot of people take. When I tried just after roundabout but it didn't work so good even with a planty of space to stop.
